titleStmt.title: The accomplish'd courtier consisting of institutions and examples, by which courtiers and officers of state may square their transactions prudently, and in good order and method / by H.W. Gent.
Traicté de la cour. Part 2. English
titleStmt.author: Refuge, Eustache de, d. 1617.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A66933 of text R23349 in the English Short Title Catalog (Wing W33A). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 249 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 84 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The accomplish'd courtier consisting of institutions and examples, by which courtiers and officers of state may square their transactions prudently, and in good order and method / by H.W. Gent.
Traicté de la cour. Part 2. English
titleStmt.author: Refuge, Eustache de, d. 1617.
H. W.
Walsingham, Francis, Sir, 1530?-1590.
Walsingham, Edward, d. 1663.

notesStmt.note: Translated into English by Edward Walsingham from a French manuscript copy of the second part of Traité de la cour, ou, Instruction des courtisans. The authorship of this work has generally been attributed to Sir Francis Walsingham, but the original was a French work by Eustache Du Refuge and was first published anonymously in Paris in 1617. Cf. DNB and Brunet.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

keywords.term: Courts and courtiers -- Early works to 1800.
